problem_prompt:
Your job is to consider a number theory problem, and leave a plan for the next person to solve it. The problem will be revealed one sentence at a time. You do not have the entire problem yet, thus just do whatever calcluations/planning you think will be useful for the next person. If you don't think you can make any progress, say so. The following is a portion of the entire problem, and the work/progress/message the previous person left for you. There may be errors in the provided work that was previously done and left for you, so check and fix them if necessary.
Find $10110_2\times10100_2\div10_2$.
solution:
It is much easier to find $10110_2\div10_2$ and then multiply by $10100_2$ than it is to do the calculations in the original order. For $10110_2\div10_2$, since the last digit of $10110_2$ is a 0, we can simply take it off to get $1011_2$. This is similar to base 10, where $10110_{10}\div10_{10}=1011_{10}$. In base 2, each place represents a power of 2, and since we're dividing by 2, each place goes down by a power 2, so each digit shifts to the right. Now we find the product of $1011_2$ and $10100_2$. $$\begin{array}{@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c}
& & &1 &0 & 1 & 1_2 & & \\
& & & \times & 1& 0 & 1& 0 & 0_2 \\
\cline{1-9}& & &1 &0 &1 &1 & & \\
& & & & & &0 & & \\
& 1 &\stackrel{1}{0}&1 &1 &0 &0 &\downarrow &\downarrow \\
\cline{1-9}
&1 &1 &0 &1 &1 &1 &0 &0_2 \\
\end{array}$$The answer is $\boxed{11011100_2}$.
